Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of painted rock art (pastoral period?), on the underside of a projecting rock shelf, showing seven human figures and four unidentified shapes. All human figures point left and face down but for the leftmost figure which is perpendicular to the others and is upright. All the human figures are infilled in dark brown. Below the perpendicular figure is an unidentified shape painted in light brown. To the right, amongst the human figures, there is another, unidentified infilled shape in light brown, in the shape of an elongated triangle with a flange at the base and a thin, bent point. To the left of this is an unidentified dark brown infilled triangle and on the bottom right there is a final unidentified white outlined shape. The top figures appear spattered with white pigment and some appear to be wearing skirts, particularly the two rightmost figures which have breasts (women?). Karkur Talh, Egypt. Scanned
Curator's comments: Detail of 2013.2034.23. This site is about 100m from 2013.2034.1-4 and some 15m up the wadi slope; A shelter about 5m by 2m with a flat overhanging ceiling. Karkur Tahl is the largest wadi (dry seasonal riverbed valley) in the sandstone eastern section of Jebel Uweinat, a granite and sandstone massif on the border of Egypt, Libya and Sudan. Karkur Talh is around 25 km long and lies mostly in Sudan, but partly within Egypt’s borders. There is an abundance of both painted and engraved rock art in shelters in the smaller side wadis. The engravings were first revealed to academia by Ahmed Hassanein in 1923 and a few photographs published in his report on the journey in National Geographic in 1924. A more comprehensive publication of rock art sites in Karkur Talh was made by Prince Kemal el Dine with Abbe Breuil in 1925 following his discovery of a painted cave in Karkur Talh. Further exploration and publications were made by numerous others including renowned explorer Ralph Bagnold’s expedition in 1931, with further exploration from László Almásy and Leo Frobenius in 1933. The largest professional exploration of the massif to date was made in 1968 by a team of Belgian scientists.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
